stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on 'Course 15', a space-themed arcade level. He programmed and refined several custom objects, including warp platforms and low-gravity zones, while also debugging significant rendering and performance issues to ensure it runs on original N64 hardware. Key discussions included a hypothetical plan to release a standalone commercial version of the game and his personal philosophy on social interactions.

development_findings.summary: The game is designed to be more challenging than Super Mario 64, but this difficulty is offset by significantly improved and more reliable player controls.
development_findings.quote: A lot of the platforming is more difficult. But the movement is so much more consistent. And it just works. So it kinda balances out.

development_findings.summary: Kaze disabled Mario's native transparency feature to solve a graphical rendering conflict with the game's custom materials, opting for a scaling animation as a creative workaround for warps.
development_findings.quote: I think my life would be easier if we disabled the ability of Mario to go transparent. Because the materials we have do not allow for it. And it's messing with Nth color.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively replacing original Super Mario 64 code not just for legal reasons, but because he finds it highly inefficient and poorly written.
development_findings.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process is iterative, moving from a high-level plan to programming necessary objects, followed by a phase of hands-on experimentation to discover fun gameplay loops.
development_findings.quote: First, I make an outline of the things I want in the level. Then I think about how I can make the level fun... And then I just start moving it around and see what's fun. And then we just keep whatever turned out to be fun.

development_findings.summary: Kaze successfully debugged a major rendering issue with an invisible bridge by diagnosing it as a file mix-up, demonstrating his persistence in solving technical problems.
The game is being developed to run on original N64 hardware, with Kaze actively testing performance and accepting frame rates around 22-25 FPS in demanding scenes.
Kaze is creating custom objects for the space level, including low-gravity zones and dynamic warp platforms that light up from below as Mario stands on them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is seriously considering creating a parallel, standalone version of the game with original IP, which could be sold legally on platforms like Steam.
context_findings.quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own? That is the idea. And that way we would legally own it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep-seated frustration with the social pleasantry 'How are you?', viewing it as an invasive and disingenuous question, which he attributes to his German cultural background.
context_findings.quote: You're so concerned about my well-being, that the first thing you ask when you see me is if I'm well? Do I seem that unstable?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is closely observing the financial success of other N64-style indie games on Kickstarter, noting high per-backer contributions as valuable data for his own potential future projects.
context_findings.quote: The average person is dropping $250 on this? This is like insane data. I need to keep this in mind.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a cynical view of the modern video game industry, believing the general quality is low, which lowers the bar for a new game to be successful.
context_findings.quote: It's one of those things that's more difficult the more difficult the competition is, and video games are fucking awful, which means the competition is not very strong.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to delay the demo release to avoid conflicting with another creator's project launch, showing consideration for the broader N64 modding community.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for creating the final art assets, reworking Kaze's placeholder graphics. This defines a clear workflow where Kaze focuses on programming and level block-outs.
biobak.quote: Probably shouldn't spend so much time on textures and stuff. Considering Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway. I should just leave it to him.

zeina.summary: Zeina designed the arcade-style carpet texture for the space level, which Kaze implemented and praised during the stream.
zeina.quote: What do you think of this carpenter that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Zeina's presence in the chat and Kaze's direct interactions with her about her contributions highlight their close personal and professional working relationship.

key_stories.title: The Standalone IP Pivot Strategy
key_stories.summary: Kaze discussed a potential major pivot for the project: creating a second, commercially viable version of the game by replacing all Nintendo IP with original content. This would allow him to sell the game on Steam, reaching a broader audience and legitimizing the years of development work.
key_stories.challenge: ROM hacks like RTYI cannot be legally sold or easily distributed to a mainstream audience, limiting the project's reach and potential for monetization.
key_stories.process: Kaze conceptualized a plan to create a parallel version of the game. This would involve swapping all Nintendo assets for original ones, altering the gameplay mechanics like movement to create a distinct product, and replacing any remaining Nintendo code to ensure legal ownership.
key_stories.outcome: The idea remains a hypothetical, but Kaze is actively considering it as a serious future strategy, influenced by the success of other indie N64-style games and the desire to reach a wider, less technical audience on platforms like Steam.
key_stories.key_quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own?

key_stories.title: Designing the Warp Platform
key_stories.summary: Faced with a technical limitation preventing a standard transparency fade, Kaze designed a new, more dynamic warp platform. He created a custom animation where Mario scales into the ground and added a light effect from below, turning a technical problem into a unique visual feature.
key_stories.challenge: A simple fade-out for warp platforms was not visually interesting and created technical problems with the game's custom rendering for Mario's model.
key_stories.process: First, Kaze disabled Mario's default transparency to fix a rendering bug. He then implemented a new warp animation using scaling. To enhance the effect, he added a dynamic light source to the platform's collision type, making Mario glow as he teleports.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a unique and visually appealing warp sequence where Mario scales down into the platform while being illuminated from below. This solution successfully bypassed the technical issue and resulted in a more polished effect.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this platform here should add a light from below, so that when you're on here, it looks like Mario is just being brightened up from the floor.
